The biggest advantage of using telescopes that detect different wavelengths of light is that each wavelength provides unique information about the objects and phenomena in the universe. By studying the universe in different wavelengths, astronomers can obtain a more complete understanding of the cosmos and the processes that shape it.

For example, visible light telescopes provide images of stars and galaxies, showing their shapes, colors, and structures. Infrared telescopes, on the other hand, can penetrate the dust clouds that often obscure visible light, revealing objects otherwise hidden from view, such as young stars and protoplanetary disks.

Radio telescopes, meanwhile, can study the universe's largest structures, such as galaxy clusters and cosmic filaments, which are difficult to observe with optical and infrared telescopes. They can also detect signals from objects that emit radio waves, such as pulsars and quasars.

X-ray and gamma-ray telescopes can study some of the most energetic phenomena in the universe, which emit high-energy radiation that is invisible to optical and infrared telescopes. This includes phenomena such as black holes, supernova remnants, and active galactic nuclei.

Overall, the use of different types of telescopes allows astronomers to study the universe in many different wavelengths, and to obtain a more complete understanding of the cosmos as a whole.
